awd_titl_txt: Open Chemistry Collaborative in Diversity Equity (OXIDE)
awd_abstract_narration:
This award from the Division of Chemistry (CHE) of the National Science Foundation, with additional support from the National Institutes of Health (National Institute of general Medical Sciences) and the Department of Energy (Basic Energy Sciences) supports Prof. Rigoberto Hernandez of the Georgia Institute of Technology and his colleagues in their efforts through the Open Chemistry Collaborative in Diversity Equity (OXIDE) at increasing participation in the chemical sciences by all members of American society, including members of groups that have been traditionally underrepresented in the sciences.  They will do this through a broad series of activities including workshops, assessments of interventions performed within chemistry departments, and broad dissemination of e.g. best practices.

Work like that of Prof. Hernandez and his colleagues is aimed at finding effective means for recruitment and retention of the most talented Americans into the chemical enterprise.  Success in these efforts will have profound implications for American economic prosperity and continued competitiveness.

por.por_cntn:
Among the most effective approaches for advancing diversity demographics in industry has been the introduction of accountability of middle managers by executives. For simplicity, we named this notion the top-down hypothesis, and extended it to the academy. We effectively treated all of the departments across the chemical discipline as a virtual company; holding the chairs accountable, not to a specific executive, but rather to their collective voice. This collective effort led us to name it as the Open Chemistry Collaborative in Diversity Equity (OXIDE). Thus the intellectual merit of this award was founded on our development of the top-down hypothesis to hold department chairs and heads accountable for advancing inclusive excellence. OXIDE acted as the convener to ensure that they answer to each other as a collective executive of this virtual company. Thus, the use of the top-down hypothesis was evidence-based and its implementation created competition between departments as they tried to outperform each other on metrics related to inclusive excellence. 

The workshops held prior to 2011 effectively employed the top-down hypothesis across the chemistry discipline were successful in creating awareness with respect to the under-represented group (URG) areas that they covered. Unfortunately, they were all one-time events. In order to have sustained accountability and to fully employ the top-down hypothesis, the heads and chairs needed to be held accountable systematically for advancing diversity equity continuously in time. As there is only one department chair or head at any given time, it is also practical and efficient to include all areas of under-representation in a single workshop because for example, they generally would not have enough time to attend separate workshops in each URG annually. 

The biennial National Diversity Equity Workshops were founded in 2011 to create precisely this systematic accountability and continuity in partnership witha chemistry department leaders. Thus, there are two primary advances from the previously offered workshops in the NDEW series: (1) Each NDEW addresses the biases and barriers faced by women, URMs, and Chemists with Disabilities (CWD) simultaneously. (2) A fourth URG, pertaining to one's sexual orientation and or identity [that is, individuals within the lesbian, gay, bisexual, transsexual, and questioning (LGBTQ) community] was added to the discussion. Thus far, through the support from this grant, four NDEWs took place. The findings from the workshops led to suggested practices that were increasingly adopted by chemistry departments. Both the suggested practices and the workshops were published in archival journals and disseminated broadly.      

OXIDE also catalogued the faculty demographics with respected to women and under-represented minorities. The results were published on the web and archival journals. OXIDE partnered with Chemical & Engineering News to disseminate the findings widely.

The broader impacts of this work was the increased diversity in chemistry faculties, and the marked improvement of effective practices to support diversity, equity and inclusion within those departments.

 


Last Modified: 03/22/2019
Modified by: Rigoberto Hernandez
